They have held government in this country for the lion's share of almost 100 years of federation.

It also amuses me when I hear them talking about not increasing taxes. What were the tax rates in Australia when the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was Treasurer of this country? I think the top marginal tax rate was into the 60c range and it was the Hawke and Keating governments that brought those tax rates down to, while still not an acceptable level I concede, a much lower level and the lowest level in the history of federation.

There is not much that can be said of this budget, Mr Deputy Speaker. It was a non-event. I do congratulate the government on its projected $2.7 billion surplus. That was expected and the financial markets would not have accepted much less. A Labor government would have, similarly, at this point in the economic cycle been striving to achieve a similar result. There are two ways you can go about producing that surplus. You can do it on the back of growth by priming the economy, getting people working again and lifting government revenues or you can do it at the expense of those who can least afford to wear the brunt of that alternative method, and that is by heavy spending cuts. Those people who have borne the brunt are those who can least afford to do so. You have got to ask yourself, with respect to the budget, `Yes, that's fine, but at what cost?' At what cost to health services? At what cost to educational standards? At what cost to the aged in our community? At what cost to working families? Growth is the way to produce a sound budget. You do not do it by whacking those who can least afford to be whacked.

Governments have very few tools available to them in terms of macro-economic management these days. Historically we have had a few of them. We have had monetary policy but these days the Reserve Bank handles that area of policy pretty well independently of the government. Governments do not have the same sort of control or ability these days to impact on or manage the economy with respect to monetary policy. We did have wages policy but, with the advent of the Workplace Relations Act, the government has now all but removed itself from any role in terms of wages policy. Really, today governments have but one economic tool available to them and that is fiscal policy. Even there the government is restricted because with the internationalisation of the economy, world markets expect us to do certain things. If we do not bring in budget surpluses or balanced budgets or any sort of budget that is acceptable to the international money markets we find ourselves in all sorts of trouble. So governments are very restricted.

But there is more to fiscal policy than just the macro economy. Fiscal policy gives governments an opportunity to redistribute wealth, to narrow the gap between the haves and the have-nots. That is a very important role for government. Indeed, that is probably what government is all about. I think you would agree, Mr Deputy Speaker. The statistician did a bit of work on this a couple of years ago. He did a study on what areas of government spending and revenue raising did the most to close the gap between the haves and the have-nots. It is an important issue. He found that in this country the difference in private income between the poorest families and the richest families—I am talking private income alone without factoring in any assistance from government—was $13 per week for the poorest families and more than $1,500 a week for the most wealthy families. That is a substantial gap, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will agree. He found that the difference in final income—that is, when you factored in assistance given by governments, assistance such as family allowance and the like—remained at $233 for the poorest families and something like $1,200 for the most wealthy families in this country.

You have to ask yourself: what part of the budget contributes most to the narrowing of that gap? Quite obviously, the raising of taxes and redistributing those taxes into cash benefits such as family allowance and pensions and other things plays a significant role. Indeed, the statistician found it narrowed the gap by about 25 per cent. But there is another very important factor, and that is the effect that provision of non-cash benefits has on the narrowing of that gap. The statistician found that that contributes to the narrowing of the gap by about 20 per cent. The provision of non-cash benefits plays a very important role in terms of the redistribution of wealth and the narrowing of the gap in this country between the haves and the have-nots. What are these non-cash benefits? They are the provision of infrastructure and services—health services, schools, roads, employment services and child-care services. However, they are the areas that this government has hit hardest not only in this budget but in all three budgets.

Where do those non-cash benefits have the greatest role to play? They have the greatest role to play in rural and regional Australia where we are sparsely populated and where services are so vital to people in those communities. The government has just thrown away that opportunity. It has thrown away one of its best opportunities to redistribute wealth in this country to ensure that all Australians can enjoy a decent standard of living.

But this budget's greatest failure is in the area of unemployment. This is the budget that runs up the white flag on unemployment. Remember all of the pre-election promises about jobs growth? You remember the pre-election period, Mr Deputy Speaker. The now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) were roaming the country crying about the state of unemployment in this country. They said it was in crisis, it was disgraceful, and that they were going to do something about it. Well, here we are debating their third budget, almost three years into their period in government, and not much has changed. Indeed, youth unemployment, the matter about which they were doing the most screaming, has gone up. What sorts of headlines do we get in my local newspaper? Just today the Newcastle Herald says, `Hunter jobs slashed again.' The Hunter region is in crisis.

talk.start.para: —It is Bob Baldwin's fault.

—I pick up on the interjection of my colleague. What is the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) doing about unemployment in the Hunter? Not much, I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Indeed, I was talking in the House on Monday about the role the government is playing in facilitating the loss of jobs in the Hunter. On that occasion, I was using the example of the exercise by Steggles of importing Korean workers to replace Australian workers. That is an exercise that is facilitated by the Howard government. Those are the sorts of headlines that we are seeing in the Hunter. There is no jobs growth whatsoever, despite those very big promises prior to the election.
—What's your mate Bob Carr done about it? Nothing.

—When BHP announced the closure of its Newcastle steelworks, there was a great hullabaloo. Politicians from both sides were falling over one another to get in first and see who could talk loudest about assistance for the people of the region as a result of that decision. The Upper Hunter Business Enterprise Centre has done a study that shows that, in comparative terms, the downturn in the coalmining and power industries is likely to have a greater impact on the Upper Hunter and areas such as the Cessnock LGA than the BHP closure had on Newcastle. But where is the recognition from government? Where is the assistance package for the Cessnock local government area, the Singleton local government area and the Muswellbrook local government area? Where is the recognition that depressed coal prices is a matter for all Australians?

speech.para: Where is the recognition that this dramatic structural adjustment in the Hunter needs to be dealt with by government? It is only the federal government that has the resources available to it to take that issue on. I heard the member for Paterson talking about the Carr government but it is only the federal government that has the resources. I wonder whether the member for Paterson supports federal government intervention for the Hunter. I know his Prime Minister does not because I wrote to the Prime Minister on 16 December last year bringing to his attention the Upper Hunter BEC study and the plight of people in my electorate. I pleaded with him to put in place an adjustment package that would, firstly, assist with economic growth and deal with economic adjustment in the area and, secondly, lend special assistance to retrenched coalminers so that they could be retrained and be given income support throughout that training period.

What was the Prime Minister's response to this very important issue in the Hunter? Nothing. I did not even get a letter, not a response at all. And the Prime Minister is not alone in that: I can give you a list of ministers of this government who are failing to respond to letters from members of parliament. This is an extraordinary development. I do not have any delusions about power. I have never overestimated my influence in this place as an opposition backbencher but I thought one thing was sacred: I thought when a member of parliament wrote to a minister he was at least entitled to a response. I thought that, if a member wrote to the Prime Minister highlighting the plight of his or her region, and seeking some assistance, that they would at the very least get a letter of sympathy. But, no; they will not even get a response. Where does that leave the people of my electorate? It leaves them in a pretty parlous state. It certainly means that a few more will be unemployed.

Let me turn now to employment services. Where do people go now that there is no CES? The member for Paterson smiles: why wouldn't he smile? He has not done too badly under the new Job Network, not too badly at all. Eight service providers with six sites in Maitland. We know why this is the case.

talk.start.para: —He's a oncer!

—As my colleague indicates, it is because he will probably only be here once and the government is going to do all it can to protect him. How many sites in Cessnock? How many service providers in Cessnock? There were to be two as two were contracted. Well, we have Employment National but the other has not surfaced. Last Friday, along with some other residents, I roamed the CBD looking for the second service provider but we could not find it. So not only is the government forcing more people out of work in my area but also when they go to look for jobs assistance it is nowhere to be found.

speech.para: All the member for Paterson can do is smile. I can appreciate his being happy that his electorate has been pork-barrelled but we should look at these matters on a regional basis. Not only should he have some sympathy for those who live in his electorate and are deserving of employment services, but he should have a look at those in my electorate and the needs of my residents. The unemployment rate in the Cessnock local government area is much higher than that in Maitland. Where is the logic in all of this? The minister says that the allocation of these contracts has gone through a due diligence process and it has all been done properly by an independent body. How can anyone possibly explain how Maitland, with a lower unemployment rate, gets six sites when Cessnock gets two? There is no explanation for that, none whatsoever.

talk.start.para: —There is: a quality member.

—A quality member! This is the member that fails to stick up for coalminers under attack by Rio Tinto. When they ring him they are simply told that it is not in his electorate. What he does not understand is that, although the coalmine is not in his electorate, the people who work there live in his electorate. I will conclude there.

speech.para: This is an appalling budget. It does nothing. It is only a precursor to the much bigger announcement of a GST in this country, something which once again is going to impact hardest on those who can least afford to bear it. And many of those live in my electorate.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Draper) adjourned.

debate.para: Motion (by Mr Nugent) proposed:
That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I draw the attention of the Main Committee once again to the poor state of the Princes Highway between Geelong and Melbourne, the increasing commercial and recreational use of that particular stretch of highway, the increasing risks of accidents to people who travel regularly on that route and the need for the federal and state governments to upgrade its status to a road of national importance and to commence committing funds for a third lane. It is disappointing to note the decreasing road expenditures over the life of the Howard government on roads and the reduced capacity of the federal government to fund stretches of highway which are not only important to the nation in a national economic sense but very important in a safety sense to the many people from Geelong who each day travel along this stretch of road to Melbourne to work.

speech.para: For example, last year's budget indicated that the national highway expenditure would rise from $680.1 million in 1997-98 to $687 million in 1998-99. In the budget just brought down by the Treasurer, we see that expenditure on the national highway will actually fall to $675.5 million. I draw the Main Committee's attention to the fact that, in Labor's last year of office, national highway expenditure was in the region of $834 million.

I mention national highway road funding in the context of this adjournment debate because the commercial traffic On the Princes Highway is estimated to be in the broad band of 14,800 to 48,800 commercial vehicles per day. That is more than most national highway routes carry in all vehicle categories, yet it is not even rated as a highway of national significance. To give members an idea of the volume of traffic on the Princes Highway between Geelong and Melbourne: it is estimated that the freeway carries 40,000 vehicles per day near the Geelong end of that stretch of highway, increasing as you move to the Westgate Bridge to 132,000 movements per day. These are quite staggering figures when you consider they are increasing by the day, the week and the month. Given the poor state of the highway surface, increasing volumes of traffic of this order have quite profound safety implications for road users.

In 1992, there were two fatal accidents and two deaths on the Princes Highway West, as we call it. That has increased to six fatal accidents and seven deaths in 1996. Over the same period, all casualties have increased from 136 to 164. It is an appalling safety record and, given the state of the road surface, the increasing usage overall, as well significant changes in the patterns of usage with the advent of B-doubles and triples, commuters literally take their life into their own hands when they pull out onto the highway to go to work. Put simply, the Princes Highway between Geelong and Melbourne has become a killer road.

I note with some disappointment the federal government's funding commitment in the budget to roads in the Ballarat and Bendigo regions. Leaving aside the fact that these are marginal Liberal electorates in Victoria, I certainly do not begrudge those communities legitimate funding for roads. But for the life of me, I cannot understand why the federal and Victorian governments have not moved to commit funding to the Princes Highway.

It is a road or a highway of national economic significance. In my electorate, we have proposals on the drawing board to vastly expand Avalon airport as an air freight centre for the export of perishable products to Asia. We also have the east coast armaments complex construction—the modified version—which the government has scaled down, but we hope it will proceed. With these two developments alone, we are going to see a massive increase in heavy vehicular traffic on this particular stretch of highway over the next five years.

In addition to that, there is the increasing popularity of the Great Ocean Road, with the increasing recreational traffic occurring, so that particular stretch of highway is going to become a nightmare of some significance. I urge the federal government to declare this a road of national importance and to move quickly to commit funding to it in the national economic interest and for the safety of commuters.

talk.start.para: —Like everyone, from the Governor-General and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) down, I feel deeply and personally sorry for the pain and suffering of my Aboriginal fellow Australians. It is true that this generation is not responsible for the paternalism and the cruelties of the past but, if my grandfather had been thrown off his property by my neighbour's great-grandfather, who had lived off the fat of the land ever since, I suspect that I would be unreconciled, even if my neighbour was otherwise my best mate. It seems to me that we white Australians, who can readily feel, for instance, the antipathy of the Orange and the Green, sometimes suffer a serious failure of imagination when it comes to appreciating the pain in the hearts of our black brothers and sisters.

speech.para: As the Prime Minister said yesterday, reconciliation is one of the great challenges of our time and one of the most important pieces of unfinished national business. Like slavery in the United States, dispossession of the Aborigines is a stain on our soul. But, together with the Prime Minister, I have always thought that repentance was better judged by deeds than words. Cultural annihilation was never the intention of official Australia. It is worth remembering Governor Phillip's instruction to live in amity with the native inhabitants. It is true that some of our forebears did poison the waterholes and massacre women and children, but that was never officially sanctioned and white men were hanged for the murder of black men as early as the 1830s.

Australia's past is not as morally simple as some promoters of a Sorry Day suggest. As anthropologist Kenneth Maddock has said, `What we are seeing is a struggle for the high moral ground, using the politics of embarrassment. The aim is to soften up your opponents by making them feel bad about themselves or their ancestors.' It is important that we remember our mistakes, but we should not forget our virtues just because not everyone is happy with the way things have turned out. The sorrow we share for the swamping of Aboriginal culture is of course a tribute to the better angels of our Western European natures.

We need to ask ourselves what benefit there is in a series of Sorry Days engendering resentment in some and guilt in others. How can we be reconciled with people who accuse us of racism? We need to ask ourselves whether sackcloth and ashes is the appropriate national garb as we enter a new century. The first Christian sermon preached in New South Wales took as its text, `What can I render unto the Lord for all his blessings towards me?', and it seems to me that, if they—who had so little—felt this way, it is surely niggardly of all of us not to feel more gratitude for the great gift of being Australian.

talk.start.para: —A number of members, including the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) and I, had the opportunity yesterday to meet with a Pakistani parliamentary delegation that is visiting Australia. I had the opportunity on several occasions, and the member for Aston had the opportunity on at least one occasion. Quite naturally, the principal area of discussion in that meeting concerned the outrageous actions of the Indian government in conducting tests with five nuclear devices earlier this month. One of those devices was a thermonuclear device. They have also tested low yield devices, which are devices that are particularly dangerous because of their tactical capacities for use in conflict. The question of India's flouting of international norms by carrying out those tests is an important matter for all in this parliament. Also, India has foreshadowed its intention to proceed to develop a missile delivery system—which further destabilises security arrangements not only on the subcontinent but also, I believe, globally.

speech.para: India in the past has claimed some moral authority in world affairs, and I think with some justification. Its independence struggle, with its emphasis on non-violence, and the lead that India provided in the non-aligned movement in the Cold War period are certainly both areas where it ought to receive recognition for its moral claim. But it really has gone a great way down the track to forgoing those claims, because of its outrageous actions in recent days.

Australia has played a leading role in the past in strides towards non-proliferation, and Australia's role in the establishment of the comprehensive test ban treaty really gives us considerable clout in terms of putting our view on these issues. One has to ask why India has sought to destabilise global non-proliferation efforts by its actions. Certainly, India's security situation is complex but it is scarcely desperate. It clearly has justifiable Great Power aspirations, but one would have thought that it would perhaps be better served as a nation by following aspects of the example of Japan, concentrating on unleashing the economic potential of the very great country that it is, and achieving consequent social benefits for its people and its neighbours, rather than by pursuing the sorts of policies it is pursuing.

Disastrously, the temptation for Pakistan now to reciprocate in kind is very strong. We and all Australians urge that country to assume some of the moral mantle that India has forgone by its actions. It is vital that sanctions on India be demonstrated to be real and effective. It is noteworthy that, whilst the World Bank indicated just the other day that it was withholding several loans, certainly the perception of the Pakistanis is that those sanctions are not particularly strong or adequate. The failure—in the Pakistani view—of the Russians, the French, and possibly the British to take economic retaliatory measures against India is, in particular, very strongly in their minds in terms of influencing their judgments.

It is also very necessary to take strong action against India in the current climate, to send a clear unequivocal measure to a range of other potential nuclear power states, including some not terribly distant, such as Iran, to indicate the consequences of the actions the world community would take if they breach international norms. It is also important to renew efforts and particularly for Australia to use its influence to renew efforts to restart the global arms control discussions, to start up the START process again, if you will excuse the pun in that, and to take steps towards negotiating an effective fissile materials cut-off regime.

We have, as I said before, got real authority there because of the performance particularly of the former government and the establishment of the Canberra Commission. There really needs to be a renewed commitment to ensuring strong economic incentives to countries like Pakistan to focus on economic development. Minister Downer's announcement the other day of a preparedness to double Australia's aid to just $6 million indicates, I think, a fairly miserly approach and one that needs to be reviewed in terms of providing real incentives for countries like Pakistan not to go down the nuclear route. There needs to be renewed international concern, I believe, about Pakistan's security position, particularly in attempting to solve the problem of Kashmir. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last Monday in the main chamber I spoke to an aspect of the budget, the allocation of $215 million over five years to the national illicit drugs strategy. I will take this time during the adjournment debate to conclude those comments. The `tough on drugs' program that this government has introduced will go a long way to resolving the problems of drugs in our society. Clearly, we would all agree that we need to start to address the cause and just not put bandaids on the effect. We can start to address that cause by educating our young people about the problems before they are of an age when they are tempted into the drug scene. We, and I mean all of us, must be more proactive in our approach to this problem of society. I will be seeking bipartisan support from my federal and state government colleagues, from members of the community, from social workers, from the police and, indeed, from the media, from all of those who can and will help, and together, perhaps, we will launch a `Hunter—tough on drugs' program.

speech.para: I also support and commend the New South Wales police in Operation Noah that is under way this week. You may ask why I am concerned about the drug problem that faces our society. My concern is not just as a father of three young children yet to face the pressures of society and the temptations of drugs, but because as a young person growing up in the streets of Bankstown I experienced the very painful side effect of drug abuse when I lost two very close friends due to heroin overdose over 20 years ago.

One of those friends, Kevin Fox, was a great bloke, like the big brother I never had. On the exterior he was rough and tough, a bikie and a tattooist. But what gave him away was his heart—a heart larger than Phar Lap's. I remember that I was away on a sales trip in Adelaide when I received a call to say that Kevin had died. He had died from an injection of heroin, a bad quality trip. The irony is that he had been clean for about six years, but the demon drug and whatever reason, a reason that we will never know, made him take that last hit. I have got to say that we miss Kevin.

Then when I was 22 there was a young lady called Ashleigh. She and I were very close. Indeed, I had taught her scuba diving and we continued scuba diving together. We became the very best of friends and, in fact, we talked about making a long-term commitment. She was an absolutely wonderful and stunningly beautiful person. It is often said that love is blind and I must say it must be. I did not know, or even suspect, that she was addicted to the demon drug of heroin. Perhaps I lived a sheltered life unaware of this problem. Perhaps I did not want to see the problem. Ashleigh was not a heavy user—from what I found out after she died, she had only used it irregularly—but she still had that dependency upon the drug. Again, it was a bad trip that was to be a final one to heaven. Unfortunately for me, it would appear that the only long-term commitment that she was able to make was to using heroin, using it right to the end of her precious life.
All of the money in the world would not bring back Kevin, or Ashleigh, or the thousands like them, but perhaps, and just perhaps, the money that we are investing can save someone like Ms H.

As I travel around my electorate I see a lot of young people hanging out. Let us not make the mistake of assuming that all these young people are vandals, gangs of violent, homeless youth, drug pushers or drug users. Some of them are simply just meeting their friends and doing no harm to anyone, not even themselves.

In relation to getting tough on drugs, though, we do need to talk the talk, walk the walk, and most importantly fight the fight so that we can rid the country of the problems that come with drugs. You never know whose son or daughter may be the next person attracted, through a variety of reasons, to this path that only ever leads to an eternal hell like no other. It may be your child, it may be mine, but regardless of whose we need to fight the fight.
Let us hope that we can turn this ship around on the bad trip and get on to a course of salvation in this drug problem that is destroying the very people of this great nation. I sincerely hope so.

talk.start.para: —Beware the cyber censors. I notice in today's Financial Review , in an article by Lenore Taylor, that the B'nai B'rith anti-defamation commission is again in full political censorship mode in relation to both the federal coalition and Queensland preference allocation procedures.

speech.para: On an only slightly more subtle but far more insidious censorship note, I would urge all members of this House and Internet users everywhere to take serious note of the B'nai B'rith's anti-defamation commission's submission to the Internet Industry Association code of practice. The Adelaide Institute web site is but one of those on the ADC's submissions hit list. The following is quoted from the Adelaide Institute's critique of the ADC submission:

The Adelaide Institute is concerned about attempts being made by the B'nai B'rith Anti-Defamation Commission to enforce censorship, not only of the Internet, but also even of email messages deemed "offensive" by extending the terms of the IIA Draft Code of Ethics to "counter racism on the Internet".

The terms of the submission made by the ADC constitute a threat to freedom of expression on the Internet. The search for truth can involve presenting viewpoints that are "controversial" and may be rejected by some, but the notion of freedom itself includes items that some people do not want to hear.

The recommendation that the Internet Service Provider be liable to excise any kind of material deemed to be "offensive" involves making the Internet Service Provider a kind of unpaid agent for the State, ensuring that material is suppressed even before it is presented.

The ADC "Racism on the Internet" submission also recommends that if the recipient of the email, who deems it "offensive", and who wants to refer it to the HREOC, the ISP must provide relevant name, address and contact details to facilitate the complaint.

Part of the difficulty here is the way that the HREOC is itself a "Star Chamber", undemocratically denying realistic chances of equal treatment under the law and a proper right of defence, with an impartial jury. It acts as an agent for political correctness.

As for the recommendation that ISP must supply all personal details of email senders for possible prosecution, this would involve a fundamental breach of trust if the supplier of information wished, for whatever reason, to keep the material confidential.

It is, for example, commonplace for whistleblowers who want to expose corruption to present material to the Internet or elsewhere but to keep their details private for fear of reprisal from the body exhibiting corruption, and there is no whistleblower protection law in Victoria. Journalists who want to reveal "politically sensitive" information often have to protect confidentiality of sources.

The ISP is invited to be a "pimp" by the ADC recommendation and cannot respect any individual's right of privacy or protection. The content should be judged on its factual content, on its truth, not on tracking down who said it simply because someone doesn't like it.

One problem about the term "racism" is that it is, itself, a vague and catchall phrase which can be distorted or stretched to be given elastic meaning. If, for example, one should expose high crime rates amongst the Chinese, then no matter how much overwhelming evidence may be presented to prove this, it can be dismissed as "racist hate" and all factual evidence discarded.

The ADC submission recommends "all Internet Service Providers to send an email message to all subscribers informing them that the publication and possession of material, such as child pornography, bomb making and racism is prohibited."

Once again, this continues to make the ISP an unpaid agent of state censorship. It is real "cute" in the way it implies that "racism" is on a par with child pornography and bomb making and, owing to the elastic nature of the term "racism"' as a "catchall" phrase, can be stretched to fit into the politically correct model.

The wording of this proviso linking "child pornography, bombing and racism" is deceptive. It is as if anyone were to say "murder, rape, arson and racism", implying that murder, rape and arson, which are clearly evil, are just as evil as "racism", which is open to argument in view of the abuse of the term itself which is often used as a smear.
The ADC submission argues that "the Internet Industry Association should publish all complaints lodged with it as well as subsequent action undertaken if the code has been infringed."

The tone of this submission appears to make the IIA judge, jury and executioner. There is no mention of appeal, grounds for an impartial trial, or examination of the grounds for prosecution. In the event of any complaint being levelled against the ADC, would it agree to having any complaint posted on its own Website?

The ADC Report suggests that "for all infringements of the Code, a system should be in place so that all ISP are informed of users denied access. This will help to ensure that someone who breaches the Code will not simply commit the same offence with another ISP."

This, of course, makes the ISP a "nark", an unpaid police agent whose job is to suppress information and keep it suppressed forever. If information supplied is based on factual material but is nevertheless unacceptable to certain vested interests, then it must evidently be suppressed forever. Would the ADC agree to such a proviso against itself?
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in support of the government's response to National Reconciliation Week and, in particular, the approach of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on this issue. The theme this year, as the Prime Minister outlined earlier, is communities working together. This is in keeping with the government's fundamental belief that the interests of indigenous people are best served by moving forward together to solve today's problems and to create a bright future for all Australians—indigenous and non-indigenous alike.

speech.para: There are some in this place and elsewhere who want to use this week as an occasion to apportion blame, to inflict guilt upon this generation for the wrongs of the past, and to encourage a victim mentality rather than a positive problem solving approach to the issues that confront us. Contrary to some opinions, the Prime Minister has personally apologised and expressed his regrets on more than one occasion in this place and in public forums. I would like to take this opportunity in this place in National Reconciliation Week to also express my sorrow and regret for the mistakes of the past.

What we need to do, as the Prime Minister has pointed out, is to acknowledge past wrongs and resolve to address the problems that we are still facing, which is exactly what the Howard coalition government is doing. At the end of its first four years in office, this government will have spent almost $700 million more in real terms on indigenous specific programs than the previous government spent in its last four years. The bulk of this is in the areas of housing and infrastructure, health, education, employment and training, and economic development.

In the area of indigenous health alone, as the Prime Minister stated yesterday, we have increased spending in real terms by 37 per cent since 1995-96. Included in this spending is a raft of new initiatives including programs to fight respiratory illnesses and immunisation against influenza. Work is also under way to respond to priority health issues such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Resources have been especially devoted to hearing and eye health. Diseases affecting health status in these areas are the causes of significant morbidity but also contribute to the relatively high level of disability within Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

I am delighted to say that we are also spending $63 million to address the recommendations of the Bringing them home report. The government has also maintained a strong commitment to the Abstudy and community development and employment programs. To address the difficulties faced by our indigenous communities we have allocated funds in areas which will bring about significant long-term improvements.

I congratulate the Prime Minister for his stance in this area of policy, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) for the many positive initiatives that this government has promoted and implemented. True reconciliation will probably not come about in our immediate generation, sadly.

talk.start.para: —Not under this government!

—How can it when our indigenous people have a higher rate of incarceration per head of population and their health care and educational needs are not met, nor are they anywhere near the standard of the rest of the population? Perhaps here, as a government, we could take a leaf from the book of Fred Hollows and provide not just eye care but comprehensive health care to remote areas by mobile caravan. What could be more simple or more effective than a mobile caravan staffed by our indigenous nurses and doctors, by those who best understand their spiritual, cultural and health needs?

speech.para: As I said, reconciliation will not come about in this generation. Rather, it will come about when all our children have been taught that to differentiate one person from another you need only to ask their name.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 24 September 1997:

question.para: Further to my question without notice (Hansard , 17 June 1997, page 5362) concerning Government purchasing, has the Government introduced initiatives to maintain and increase the policy of 10% of Commonwealth purchases being made from small business; if so, what.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: On 8 August 1997 Commonwealth, State and Territory Procurement and Construction Ministers agreed to endorse the adoption of the `National Action on Small to Medium Enterprises in Government Procurement' as an agreed strategy to im prove the access of SMEs to Government procurement opportunities, especially in regional Australia. The agreed national actions include measures that:
. reduce the cost of doing business for SMEs and for government;
. encourage greater participation by SMEs in the contract chain;
. promote the benefits to SMEs of the use of electronic commerce; and
. give greater consideration to the regional impact of government procurement decision making.

The Department of Finance and Administration is progressing initiatives to advance the national actions. The former National Procurement Board also conducted seminars around Australia and invited SMEs to comment on aspects of Government procurement.

The Government announced new streamlined and simplified Commonwealth purchasing arrangements in December 1997 to cut the cost of doing business with Federal Government departments and to provide greater opportunities for small business to participate in Government markets.
The key initiatives included:
. maintenance of the Government's election commitment that Commonwealth departments and agencies source at least 10% of their purchases from small and medium enterprises (SMEs);
. inclusion of industry development requirements and opportunities for SMEs in tender documents for major projects valued at over $10 million;
. abolition of the commission imposed on businesses supplying to government under Common Use Arrangements with effect from December 1997;

. establishment of a pre-qualification scheme for businesses supplying in specific markets where the government is a major purchaser. The primary aim of the scheme is to reduce the cost for suppliers and buyers in doing business;

. establishment in March 1998 of a Purchasing Advisory and Complaints Service within the Department of Finance and Administration to assist suppliers (particularly SMEs) with problems they may experience with departmental purchasing processes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: Has the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) identified standard terminal arrivals route related procedures which do not follow accepted world best practice: if so, (a) which procedures, (b) in what way do they fail to comply with world best practice and (c) what reasons has BASI discovered for world best practice not being achieved.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) published a report in January 1997 entitled An Analysis of Incidents Involving Aircrew Failing to Comply with Air Traffic Clearances June to August 1996. The analysis included a review of the development and design of standard arrival routes (STARs) in Australia and also identified a number of then current air traffic control (ATC) procedures relating to STARs which did not follow accepted worldwide practice.

(b)and (c) BASI's analysis found that generally, worldwide practice is for ATC to issue a STAR that leads an aircraft to a position from which an instrument approach can be made. However, on the basis of STARs procedures in place during the survey period June to August 1996, this practice was not always the case in Australia.

For example, STARs then currently in place at Melbourne generally positioned the aircraft to join an instrument approach, whereas at Sydney, Brisbane and Perth, STARs culminated with an expectation that the aircraft would be vectored by radar to join the final approach course.

Furthermore, ATC could instruct aircraft to cancel and subsequently resume flying a STAR, a procedure which is not in accordance with accepted international practice. BASI's analysis also found that compared with accepted worldwide practice, many Australian STARs included lengthy transition legs which aircraft were required to fly from an airways route to join the STAR.
In its report, BASI made a number of recommendations to Airservices Australia which addressed issues associated with aligning STARs procedures to accepted worldwide practice including the need to:
. minimise vectoring aircraft within the STAR environment
. minimise the practice of instructing aircraft to resume a STAR after having been vectored off a STAR
. ensure that STARs at all locations are designed with consistent design principles
. ensure STAR designs are compatible with aircraft flight management systems (FMS) especially where STARs are not runway specific.

subdebateinfo.title: Proposed Second Sydney Airport: Rail Link
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2630)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Has his Department entered negotiations with the NSW Government to site a rail link between Glenfield and the proposed second Sydney Airport at Badgerys Creek; if so, at what stage are the negotiations.
(2) Has it been proposed to acquire land owned by Hurlstone Agricultural High School in Glenfield to facilitate the process.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The suitability of the Badgerys Creek site for the development of a major airport is presently the subject of an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) process. The Draft EIS discusses two alternative route options for providing rail access between Glenfield and Badgerys Creek. Investigations undertaken by the Commonwealth and the NSW Government some years ago have been taken into account in developing the rail route options.

Responsibility for acquisition of land for the expansion of Sydney's metropolitan rail network rests with the NSW Government. There is no current action by the Commonwealth to fund the acquisition of any land for a possible rail corridor between Glenfield and the Badgerys Creek airport site. Any Commonwealth involvement in the provision of rail access to Badgerys Creek will be dependent on the outcome of the second Sydney airport EIS process.

subdebateinfo.title: Judicial Committee of the Privy Council
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2700)

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 March 1998.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The source of the following information is Whitaker's Almanac 1998.

(a) The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council is primarily the final court of appeal for the United Kingdom dependent territories and those independent Commonwealth countries which have retained the avenue of appeal upon achieving independence as follows—Antigua and Barbuda, The Bahamas Barbados, Belize, Brunei, Dominica, The Gambia, Jamaica, Kiribati, Mauritius, New Zealand, St Christopher and Nevis, St Lucia, St Vincent and the Grenadines, Trinidad and Tobago, and Tuvalu. The Committee also hears appeals from the Channel Islands and the lsle of Man.

(b) Since the answer to the House of Representatives Question No. 1927, appeals to the Privy Council are no longer allowed from the following countries and territories Akrotiri, Bermuda, British Antarctica Territory, British Indian Ocean Territory, Cayman Islands, Dhekelia, Falkland Islands, Gibraltar, Guernsey, Hong Kong, Jersey, Monserrat, Pitcairn, St Helena, Turks and Caicos Islands and Virgin Islands.

subdebateinfo.title: Essendon Airport: Touch and Go Circuits
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2730)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 10 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that on 24 January 1998 between 6 p.m. and 6.10 p.m. an aircraft with call sign Oscar Victor Oscar Harvard made four touch and go circuits at Essendon Airport involving ten movements including the proper take-of and landing.
(2) Is it also a fact that the pilot, in asking for clearance for landing at Point Cook, observed that he would upset the neighbours if he did more touch and goes at Essendon Airport.
(3) Are the operations described on part (1) inappropriate for Essendon Airport; if so what action will he take to ensure that they are undertaken at Point Cook rather than Essendon.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Airservices Australia advise that the aircraft in question operated as described except that the tenth movement was about one hour later when the aircraft returned from Point Cook.
(2) Airservices Australia advises that it has no reports on this matter.

(3) Circuits by single-engined aircraft are permitted at Essendon for the purpose of test flights and pilot endorsements. Airservices Australia advises that it's operational procedures do not give Air Traffic Controllers the authority to question the purpose of particular flights.

entry.para: Section 1
Outline of Proposal
The Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) is seeking tenders from interested companies prepared to supply temporary employees (Executive Assistants (EA's) on a short term basis.
The Department is keen to formalise arrangements with a single provider or panel of providers to ensure a consistently high standard of service when hiring temporary employees.
The following points should be considered when formulating the tender response:
a. a clear understanding of the devolved operating environment in the Department
b. the cost effectiveness and deliver of EA services
c. the maintenance of a minimum number of temporary employees with Departmental knowledge obtained from a specifically tailored EA's induction process provided through the Department
d. provide operating standards throughout the life of the agreement through performance evaluation
e. have a flexible approach to providing required staffing numbers
f. uphold confidentiality agreements.
Full conditions and interpretation fo the Tender are set out below.
The contract shall be for a one (1) year period upon which time the tender will be re-examined.
The Department reserves the right not to proceed with the Tender process in the event that it is not cost effective.
SECTION 2
EXECUTIVE ASSISTANTS GENERAL INFORMATION
DPIE is seeking to enter into a partnership arrangement with a supplier to provide temporary EA's with an operating knowledge of DPIE on an `as required' basis.
DPIE has 90—100 EA's of which approximately 20% are temporary contracted employees. The length of tenure can range from 1 day to 3 months and longer in some circumstances.
Prospective tenderers must be able to provide temporary EAs at each level within the ASO3-ASO5 range
- the level based on the extent to which the EA's assessed relevant skills and experience meet the selection criteria.
SECTION 3—
TEMPORARY EXECUTIVE ASSISTANTS SELECTION CRITERIA
High level of secretarial ability:
a. 55-65 words per minute,
b. dictaphone and/or shorthand experience.
Demonstrated ability to use both Apple Macintosh and IBM PC's including software such as:
a. Excel spreadsheet
b. Word 6
c. Windows 95
d. electronic mail
e. electronic diary.

Demonstrated high level of initiative and organisational skills, including the ability to judge priorities and demonstrated ability to work alone and initiate action without detailed guidance or supervision.
Well developed oral communication skills and the ability to coordinate effectively within and outside the organisation.
Demonstrated ability to manage a busy office, with a high degree of timeliness, accuracy and attention to detail.
Demonstrated ability to work in a team environment, and display a professional approach to the work place.
Demonstrated ability to work in a changing environment, ie be flexible, adaptable and innovative.
A demonstrated professional approach to the workplace
• The extent to which these criteria are met should determine the salary point at which the temporary EA will be employed.
SECTION 4—
CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT OF TEMPORARY EXECUTIVE ASSISTANTS
The successful Agency will be responsible for all payments to the Temporary EA's such as:
a. hourly rates, including overtime rates
b. any on costs such as:
• workers compensation
• superannuation
• payroll tax
• income tax etc
c. any minimum charge rates for less than full day.
Oncosts to be identified by Agencies when submitting their tenders.
DPIE will be responsible for the costs of DPIE specific training (eg. induction program).
It is preferred that temporary EA's be considered employees of the Agency and not of DPIE
a. this means that on-going temporary employees will have the same opportunity to apply for vacant positions as outside candidates
- they will not be considered on-going employees of DPIE
- this needs to be conveyed by the Agency to the people they supply as DPIE temporary staff under this agreement
b. penalty fees need to be identified by the Agencies in the event of a temp gaining permanent employment with the department
Accounts will be settled based on timesheets approved by the EA's supervisor
• timesheets to be supplied by the successful tenderer.
SECTION 5—
DRAFT CONTRACT
The draft terms of contract are at Attachment 1.
• They will apply to any successful tender for the provision of temporary employees under this Request for Tender.
SECTION 6—
SUBMISSION OF TENDERS
All Tenders must be delivered by hand to the nominated person at the address below:
Helen Versluis, DPIE Training & Conference Centre, Business Services, Department of Primary Industries and Energy, Core 5 Level 5 Wing 5, Edmund Barton Building, BARTON ACT 2600
Helen Versluis, DPIE Training & Conference Centre, Business Services, Department of Primary Industries and Energy, GPO Box 858, CANBERRA ACT 2601
No tender shall be deemed to have been accepted until acceptance is formally notified by the Department.
The deadline for lodgement of Tenders is 1 August 1997. Tenders must be lodged on or before the Tender deadline.

If Tenderers become aware of any discrepancy, error or omission in their tender and wish to lodge a correction or additional information, it must be in writing and lodged prior to the Tender deadline.
The deadlines set for lodgement of Tender is extended only by written notice from the Department. Any extension notice will be given the same distribution as for the original Request for Tender.

Tender documents must be enclosed in a sealed envelop or other sealed container endorsed with "Request for Tender identification HQSCEAT" and the deadline set for lodgement of Tenders. The Tender, any attachments and supporting documentation must be in English.

The submission of supporting material must be clearly indicated in the formal Tender document. Material presented as supporting material which effectively alters the formal Tender will not be admitted for evaluation. Tenderers must ensure that the Tender specifically responds to every RFT statement of requirements. The Tender must be clear and precise and must refer, where appropriate, to page or paragraph numbers in any manuals or documentation which form part of the Tender. The Department will not accept responsibility for any misunderstanding arising from the failure by the Tenderer to comply with the requirements of the Section. Tenderers must note that those Tenders that do not reasonably satisfy the requirements of this Section or are insufficient to reasonably allow evaluation of the offer may be excluded from further consideration. Where there is no response to a requirement of the RFT, the Tenderer shall be deemed not to comply with the stated requirement for evaluation purposes.

Three (3) copies of Tenders and one (1) copy of supporting material must be submitted so that they will be received at the address previously stipulated by the closing date and time. The original is to be marked Copy No 1, Copy No 2 etc. respectively. In the event of any discrepancy between copies and the original, the original will prevail.
All documentation received as part of the Tenderer's response will be treated as commercial-in-confidence.

Any Tender (including a Tender already received at another point in the office of the Department) is considered late if it is handed to the nominated officer any time after the official deadline for the lodgement of Tenders.

A Tender received after the deadline for lodgement (as stated in the RFT) shall be opened and registered separately. It may be admitted to the Evaluation Process if, at the absolute discretion of the Department, the Tenderer was not likely to have had any opportunity to obtain an unfair advantage from the late submission of the Tender. The Department may however, at its absolute discretion, reject any Tenders received after the deadline for lodgement.

The lowest tender may not necessarily be accepted and no Tender shall be deemed to have been accepted unless and until a contract is signed by both the DPIE representative and the successful Tenderer. The draft contract at Attachment 1 will be the basis for the final contract.

In consideration of DPIE undertaking to give fair consideration to and take into account of the Tender with other Tenders received, but for no other consideration, all Tender documents submitted in response to the RFT shall become the property of the Commonwealth. Notwithstanding the above, intellectual property in the information contained in the Tender documents shall remain vested in the Tenderer.
SECTION 7—
CONFIDENTIALITY AND DISCLOSURE OF CERTAIN INFORMATION

The Commonwealth is required by law to publish summary details of most of its contracts in the Commonwealth Purchasing and Disposals Gazette and to disclose to members of the public such details additional to those published about a contract as it thinks fit. In the absence of any contrary provision in a contract, such additional details may include unit prices for items covered by the contract, rates for chargeable work and other details about the items and conditions of the contract.

Information submitted by a Tenderer shall be treated by DPIE as `Commercial in Confidence' to the extent necessary and that information shall be protected from disclosure, subject to any lawful obligations on DPIE to disclose information or any purposes of the Evaluation Process (whereby any third parties shall be informed of the confidentiality attached to that information and required to adequately protect that information).

Each Tenderer acknowledges that DPIE is subject to the operation of the Freedom of Information Act 1982, which allows the public access to government documents although, subject to the Act, the business, commercial or financial affairs of an organisation or undertaking shall generally not be disclosed.
The Tenderer shall indicate which information, if any, contained in its Tender or in any supporting information is provided on the basis that it is not to be disclosed without its prior consent.

The Department's obligation and discretionary powers as to disclosure of the above mentioned information are in addition to its powers, rights and obligations under the Freedom of Information Act 1982.
SECTION 8—
COMPLETION OF TENDER

The Tender pricing for these Services is to be stated in Australian dollars and the Tender price is to include all costs connected with tendering for, and the performance of supplying the Department with temporary Executive Assistant services, the subject of the RFT.
Tenders and supporting material shall be in the English language and any other details to be included in the Tender, shall be legible and in typed format (including computer generated printing).
Any alterations and erasures in a Tender shall be initialled by the Tenderer.

Other than documents provided by the Commonwealth as part of this RFT, Tenderers shall obtain for themselves, at their own responsibility and expense, any information necessary for the preparation of their Tenders.
Failure by a Tenderer to provide all information sought in the RFT may at the Commonwealth's absolute discretion, render the Tender ineligible for admission to the Tender Evaluation Process.
SECTION 9—
TENDER DOCUMENTS AND LICENSE TO COPY
The property in documentation included in or associated with a Tender shall vest in the Commonwealth.
The Commonwealth shall have a permanent, irrevocable, royalty-free license to copy any Tender or associated material for the purposes of the evaluation process.
SECTION 10—
TENDER ASSESSMENT

Tenders will be assessed on the basis of the tender representing the best value for money. In considering the best value for money the following matters (among others and not in any priority), may be taken into account together with any additional matters referred to in Sections 1—9 above:
a. performance of the tenderer in respect of projects of a similar magnitude;
b. experience of key personnel;
c. tender price and pricing structure; and
d.compliance with Australian Government requirements referred to in the RFT.
SECTION 11—
COMMUNICATION WITH TENDERERS
The Department reserves the right absolutely to engage in discussions with, or seek clarification orally or in writing about any matter from any Tenderer at any stage of the evaluation process.

The Department reserves the right absolutely to make a short list of any Tenderers and seek further information or final offers from those Tenderers before choosing one or any of them to enter an agreement. In the event of a short list being compiled by the Department, Tenderers not on the short list shall be advised of that fact as soon as is practicable.

The Department (through the Groups) reserves the right absolutely to not to make a short list of any Tenderers and to enter an agreement with a Tenderer without seeking further information from other Tenderers.
SECTION 12—
PRICES AND DISCOUNTS
Tenderers shall give firm prices and shall not offer prices by reference to the prices made by other Tenderers.
Any potential price variations shall be clearly justified in the Tender, including a mechanism for minimising detrimental risk to the Department from such variations.

Tenderers may indicate if any discount is allowed for early payment of accounts. Tenderers may offer settlement discounts for payment within periods of less than 30 days, but, in assessing Tenders, the Department reserves the right absolutely to only consider 30 days' settlement discounts from the date upon which an invoice for payment under an agreement is received by the Department.
For the purpose of calculating settlement discounts, payment of an account shall be deemed to have been made at the date on which the appropriate cheque is drawn by the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth reserves the absolute discretion to add to, delete from, or otherwise amend, vary, withdraw or re-issue the RFT (including the Conditions of Tender) at any time whatsoever. The Department shall make reasonable endeavours to inform any prospective tenderers that have sought, or been issued with, an RFT of any variations to the RFT.
SECTION 13—
ACCEPTANCE OF TENDER
The Department may enter into an agreement relating to a Tender for the whole or part of that Tender.
The Department is not bound to enter into an agreement for the lowest of any Tender.

Each Tender shall remain in force for at least 90 days after the deadline for lodgement or until a Tenderer expressly notifies the Department's nominated person in writing that its Tender has been withdrawn, whichever is the later.
Where the Department accepts a Tender, the Tenderer shall execute such documentation as the Commonwealth requires to bring an appropriate agreement into being.
No legal relationship shall exist between the parties (in law or equity) until an agreement has been executed in the appropriate form by both (or all relevant) parties.
SECTION 14—
OWNERSHIP OF DOCUMENTS

In consideration of the Department undertaking to give fair consideration to and take into account the Tender with the other Tenders, but for no other consideration, all Tender documents submitted in response to the RFT shall become the property of the Commonwealth. Notwithstanding the above, intellectual property in the information contained in the Tender documents shall remain vested in the Tenderer.
SECTION 15—
ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS

Commonwealth policy is to maximise employment and training opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders peoples. Tenderers must state what opportunities, if any, for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are proposed if the tender is successful.
SECTION 16—
INTERPRETATION
In this RFT, unless the contrary intention appears:

a. "Commonwealth" means the Commonwealth of Australia, including but not limited to, unless the contrary intention appears, the Commonwealth as represented by the Groups and/or the Department, its authorised employees, contractors or agents.

b. "Department" means the Commonwealth's Department of Primary Industry and Energy, or such other government agency or department as may, from time to time, administer the Evaluation Process and any relevant agreement on behalf of the Commonwealth.
c. "Evaluation Process" means the process of issuing the RFT, liaising with Tenderers, receiving and evaluating Tenders and executing any agreements related to this RFT.
d. "Deadline for lodgement of Tenders" means the time and date by which a Tender is to be submitted by a Tenderer, as stated in the RFT.
e. "Request for Tender (RFT)" means the invitation from the Department for a prospective tenderer to submit a Tender.

f. "Tender" means the tender lodged by a Tenderer in response to the RFT and includes any supplementary material supplied by the Tenderer at the request of the Commonwealth after the deadline for lodgement of Tenders.
g. "Tenderer" means a person who lodges a Tender in response to the RFT.
Unless the context otherwise requires, words importing the one gender shall include the others and words importing the singular number shall include the plural and the plural the singular.

The word "person" shall include a company and any other body, whether corporate or unincorporated, and shall include the personal representative of a deceased person and any other legal successor to a person.
Unless the context otherwise requires, a reference to an Act is to an Act of the Commonwealth Parliament and, if that Act has been or is amended, is a reference to that Act as amended.
Where any word or phase is given a defined meaning, any other part of speech or other grammatical form in respect of that word or phrase has a corresponding meaning.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 11 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Has he, his office or his Department had discussions about the proposed fanning out of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport flights over the eastern suburbs of Sydney and the introduction of mode 6A; if so, (a) with whom were the discussions held and (b) when were they held.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to a press release entitled "Joe Hockey and Mode 6A" issued by the Member for Wentworth on 3 March 1998; if so, are statements relating to the matter referred to in part (1) which are contained in the press release accurate.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Neither I nor my office have been involved in discussions on the fanning out of flight paths over the eastern suburbs.

The possibility of fanning out of flight paths over the eastern suburbs was raised briefly, but not taken up, at the meeting of the Implementation and Monitoring Committee held on 20 January 1998. The introduction of mode 6A was discussed at the meetings of the Implementation and Monitoring Committee held on 20 January 1998, 17 February 1998 and 10 March 1998. A representative of the Department was present at these meetings.
(2) I and Members of the Implementation and Monitoring Committee were aware of the proposed mode 6A on the date of the media release.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 26 March 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No.37 (Hansard , 20 August 1996, page 3286) what is the (a) priority status of the proposed construction of on and off ramps south of Brooks Road on the M5 freeway at Ingleburn, NSW; (b) progress of discussions between his Department and the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority regarding this matter and (c) expected commencement date for the project.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) No decision has yet been made on the priority status of funding for construction of the F5 ramps. The Government is funding a $100,000 traffic study in 1997/98 to investigate the need for additional entry and exit ramps along the F5. The study, to be completed by mid-1998, is examining the need for ramps at the intersections of Raby Road, St Andrews Road, Campbelltown Road and Brooks Road in the Ingleburn and Minto area.

(b) The Department of Transport and Regional Development has discussed the possible need for additional ramps with the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority (RTA) in the context of the National Highway forward program in NSW. These discussions have also raised the possible need to develop joint funding arrangements with NSW, relevant councils and private sector developers.
(c) A commencement date and funding arrangements will be determined when the results of the current study are available.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal Organisations: Supply of Motor Vehicles
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2871)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1998:

question.para: What sum has been spent with each vehicle manufacturer in supplying vehicles to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and other Commonwealth funded Aboriginal organisations in each year since 1993.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Nil. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission does not deal with vehicle manufacturers, however it sources its vehicles through DASFLEET.

Aboriginal organisations can be funded for the purchase of motor vehicles to assist in the completion of their funded activities. Where motor vehicles are purchased it is the client who decides what type of vehicle most addresses their need.
It is not feasible to compile a definitive response, even to the extent that it would be possible, due to the level of resources it would require.
GOVERNMENT AGENCIES
Aboriginal Hostels Limited
The Aboriginal Hostels Limited has not directly paid a sum of money to any vehicle manufacturer for the supply of vehicles, in each year since 1993.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation does not purchase vehicles. The small number of vehicles utilised by the ATSICDC is obtained through DASFLEET and ownership of the vehicles rests with that organisation.
Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Studies
AIATSIS has a policy of owning rather than leasing vehicles. The following prices are the amount spent (as asked for) ie purchase price after trade-in.
1993 Mitsubishi $12,464; 1994 ditto $7447; 1995 ditto nil Ford $11,189; 1996 ditto $10,999; 1997 ditto nil Ford $9,255.
Torres Strait Regional Authority

The Torres Strait Regional Authority was created on July 1 1994. All TSRA administration vehicles are leased through DASFLEET. Our record system does not allow us to identify individual lease payments only a combined monthly lease payment is made for all cars. Combined lease payments for administration vehicles are as follows: 1994/95—$13,886; 1995/96—$22,482; 1996/97—$20,292; 1997/98—$23,858 (July to April).
The following make of vehicles are currently leased from DASFLEET: Toyota Camry, Nissan Navara, Toyota Spacia, Ford Futura.
The following are vehicles that have been previously leased from DASFLEET: Toyota Tarago, Toyota Camry, Toyota Ute, Toyota Tarago.

Organisations and Councils funded through TSRA programs may purchase vehicles if they are required for the effective running of that organisation. Each Council/Organisation decides which vehicle most suits the need of their organisation. As the TSRA is not involved in the daily administration of these Councils/Organisations the TSRA is not involved in the decision as to what type of vehicles to purchase. However, as per the TSRA grant conditions before the purchase of any vehicle any Council/Organisation must obtain three quotes to ensure value for money is obtained.
The majority of vehicles purchased by island councils from Commonwealth funds are in order to operate the Community Development Employment Programs.
Indigenous Land Corporation

The Indigenous Land Corporation (ILC) has not purchased any motor vehicles for use by ILC staff since its establishment on 1 June 1995. The ILC's current in-house motor vehicle requirements are met through the term leasing of four (4) Holden and two (2) Mitsubishi motor cars from DASFLEET in Adelaide, Perth and Brisbane and one (1) Holden motor car from City Holden in Adelaide.

Mogila Merino Stud Pty Ltd (ACN 078 466 761), a wholly owned subsidiary of the ILC, purchased several new and second hand motor vehicles for on-farm use at Mogila Station, NSW. The cost of purchase of these vehicles has been partially offset by a recent clearance sale of surplus vehicles, plant and machinery acquired as part of the initial "walk-in, walk-out" purchase of the property. The decision by the company to do so was a commercial one based on its continued successful trading position.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 8 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Do proposed flight paths exist in conjunction with the draft Brisbane Airport master plan released in March 1998: if so, (a) why were they not released with the draft master plan and (b) will he ensure they are released immediately.
(2) What action will be taken to ensure that the effects of noise generated by increased air traffic over Brisbane and the number of residents affected are minimised.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The master plan process exposes the community to the airport owner's vision for the possible future development of the airport. It does not provide approval, or imply that approval will be given, for any major projects such as new runways. Master plans have previously been released for Brisbane Airport in 1983, 1991 and 1995. None of these previous master plans have included flight paths for the proposed parallel runway. (a) The timing of the release of flight paths is primarily a matter for the airport owner. (b) Flight paths will be an important part of the environmental impact statement that will be required as part of any Major Development Plan such as a new runway, if that development were to be proposed in several years time. The Airports Act process does not allow a runway to be constructed until flight paths and all other environmental impacts are fully known to the community through an environmental impact statement process.

(2) Brisbane Airport Corporation Limited (BACL) has provided information to the community which gives its commitment to minimising noise impacts on the community wherever and whenever practicable, in consultation with other stakeholders. The Corporation indicates that managing aircraft impacts to acceptable levels is a matter for the airlines, Airservices Australia, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the Corporation itself, and land use planning authorities such as Brisbane City Council and State government agencies. Importantly, under the Airports Act 1996, any Major Development Plan for constructing a new runway or extending the length of a runway is required to set out the airport owner's plans for managing aircraft noise intrusion, developed in consultations with the airlines, local government bodies in the vicinity of the airport, and the local community.
